evidence: Locke and Newton developed a close friendship after the Glorious Revolution. They corresponded extensively on theological matters, particularly regarding Newton's anti-Trinitarian views.
Voltaire spent 1726-1729 in England and became Locke's greatest French popularizer. His Letters on the English devoted multiple letters to explaining Locke's empiricism and political thought.
Hume's Treatise of Human Nature explicitly engages with Locke's Essay Concerning Human Understanding. Hume extended Locke's empiricism to its skeptical conclusions.
Rousseau's Emile drew heavily on Locke's Some Thoughts Concerning Education. Rousseau's social contract theory engaged directly with Locke's Two Treatises.
Montesquieu visited England in 1729-1731 and studied British institutions. His theory of separation of powers was influenced by his reading of Locke.
Condillac's entire philosophical project was an extension of Locke's empiricism. His Essay on the Origin of Human Knowledge developed Locke's ideas into systematic sensationalism.
Voltaire, with Émilie du Châtelet, was the primary popularizer of Newtonian physics in France. His Elements of the Philosophy of Newton introduced Newton's ideas to French audiences.
D'Alembert's mathematical physics built directly on Newton's mechanics. His Traité de dynamique applied and extended Newtonian principles.
Kant's early work accepted Newtonian physics and sought to provide its metaphysical foundations. His Critique of Pure Reason addressed how Newtonian science is possible.
Wolff systematized and popularized Leibniz's philosophy for German universities. His rationalist system dominated German academic philosophy until Kant's critical turn.
The Newton-Leibniz calculus priority dispute was one of the most famous scientific controversies. The Royal Society's investigation sided with Newton.
Co-editors of the Encyclopédie (1751-1772). D'Alembert wrote the famous Preliminary Discourse. He withdrew from active editing in 1758 after controversy.
Early close friendship; Rousseau contributed music articles to Encyclopédie. Break occurred ~1757 over philosophical differences and personal conflicts.
Break occurred ~1757 over Rousseau's rejection of theater in Letter to d'Alembert and personal conflicts. Diderot alluded critically to Rousseau in published works.
Modest but respectful correspondence. Met only once in person (1778, shortly before Voltaire's death). Both were central to Encyclopédie project.
Extensive correspondence—529 letters documented between them, making d'Alembert one of Voltaire's most frequent correspondents.
Diderot was a regular at d'Holbach's salon, attending twice-weekly dinners for decades. They collaborated on materialist and atheist publications.
Jaucourt was the most prolific Encyclopédie contributor (~17,288 articles, 25% of text), working under Diderot's editorship.
D'Alembert, as Permanent Secretary of the Académie française, mentored Condorcet. Condorcet frequented Julie de Lespinasse's salon where d'Alembert presided.
Intellectual partnership and romantic relationship. They collaborated at Cirey on Newtonian physics; du Châtelet's translation of Newton's Principia was supported by Voltaire.
Extensive correspondence beginning before Frederick's accession. Voltaire stayed at Frederick's court 1750-1753. Over 800 letters between them.
Regular correspondence; Catherine sought Voltaire's approval and advice on reforms. She called him 'my master' and purchased his library after his death.
Famous antagonism. After Rousseau's Discourse on Inequality, Voltaire mocked his primitivism. They exchanged hostile pamphlets.
Famous meeting at the Académie des Sciences in April 1778, where they publicly embraced to great acclaim. Symbolized the union of American and French Enlightenment.
Both hosted important philosophical salons. Helvétius attended d'Holbach's dinners; they shared materialist and utilitarian views.
Hume visited d'Holbach's salon during his Paris years. Famous anecdote: Hume expressed skepticism about atheists' existence; d'Holbach replied he was dining with seventeen of them.
Rousseau attended d'Holbach's salon but became estranged. He later accused the 'coterie holbachique' of conspiring against him.
D'Holbach's materialism in The System of Nature developed La Mettrie's earlier mechanical materialism into a comprehensive philosophical system.
The Spirit of the Laws directly influenced Madison's constitutional theory, particularly the separation of powers doctrine. The Federalist Papers cite Montesquieu extensively.
Turgot was Condorcet's mentor and patron. Condorcet wrote Turgot's biography after his death and continued his work on progress and economics.
Smith met Turgot in Paris during his tour as tutor to the Duke of Buccleuch. They discussed economics; Smith acknowledged French economists' influence.
Turgot was closely associated with the Physiocrats, though he developed his own economic theory. He knew Quesnay through court circles and the Encyclopédie project.
Condillac tutored Rousseau's nephew and moved in overlapping Parisian intellectual circles. Both contributed to the Encyclopédie.
Morellet translated Adam Smith's Wealth of Nations into French, helping disseminate classical economics in France.
Damilaville served as intermediary for the philosophes' correspondence, using his position in the tax administration to help circulate letters and clandestine texts.
Close friendship, arguably the central relationship of the Scottish Enlightenment. Smith was with Hume during his final illness. Hume named Smith his literary executor.
Smith studied under Hutcheson at Glasgow University. Smith later described Hutcheson as 'the never to be forgotten Hutcheson.'
Though they never met, Hume engaged extensively with Hutcheson's moral philosophy. Hutcheson read and commented on Hume's Treatise in draft.
Kant famously wrote that Hume 'awakened me from my dogmatic slumber.' Hume's skepticism about causation provoked Kant's critical philosophy.
Hume offered refuge to the persecuted Rousseau in England. The relationship rapidly deteriorated into a famous public quarrel. Hume published their correspondence to vindicate himself.
Reid's Inquiry into the Human Mind was written explicitly against Hume's skepticism. Reid founded Common Sense philosophy as an alternative.
Reid succeeded Adam Smith as Professor of Moral Philosophy at Glasgow when Smith left to tutor the Duke of Buccleuch.
Kames was an early patron and encourager of Hume, providing intellectual support and social connections.
Kames employed the young Smith and provided patronage that helped launch his career. Smith delivered his first public lectures under Kames's sponsorship.
Both were central members of Edinburgh's intellectual clubs (Select Society, Poker Club). They socialized regularly and discussed philosophy.
Ferguson and Smith were colleagues and friends in Edinburgh's intellectual circles. Both contributed to Scottish debates on commercial society.
Robertson and Hume were close friends and fellow historians in Edinburgh. Robertson led the 'Moderate Party' in the Church of Scotland.
Stewart was Smith's student and later biographer. His Account of the Life and Writings of Adam Smith is a primary source for Smith's life.
Stewart studied under Reid at Glasgow and became the primary transmitter of Scottish Common Sense philosophy to the 19th century.
During Hume's Paris years as secretary to the British embassy, he became close with d'Alembert. They corresponded on philosophy and the Rousseau affair.
Smith met Voltaire at Ferney during his French tour with the Duke of Buccleuch. Though the meeting was brief, Smith later expressed admiration for Voltaire.
Smith met Quesnay and the Physiocrats in Paris. He praised Quesnay highly and reportedly intended to dedicate Wealth of Nations to him.
Mendelssohn won the Berlin Academy prize in 1763 over Kant. They corresponded and met when Mendelssohn visited Königsberg in 1777. Both answered 'What is Enlightenment?' in 1784.
Kant was trained in the Leibniz-Wolffian tradition; his early pre-critical works are Wolffian. The Critique of Pure Reason was partly a response to Wolffian rationalism.
Kant used Baumgarten's Metaphysica as his teaching text for decades. Kant's aesthetic theory in the third Critique engaged with Baumgarten's founding of aesthetics.
Herder studied under Kant at Königsberg. Though Herder later moved toward Romanticism, Kant's influence remained formative.
Kant famously said Rousseau taught him to respect humanity. Rousseau's influence is visible in Kant's moral philosophy, particularly regarding human dignity.
Close friendship central to the German Enlightenment. Lessing based the character of Nathan in Nathan the Wise on Mendelssohn. They collaborated on aesthetic criticism.
Lessing's aesthetic theories and his Laocoon influenced Herder's development, though Herder moved toward more historicist views.
Frederick recalled Wolff from exile upon his accession (1740). Wolff had been expelled from Halle by Frederick William I in 1723.
Frederick offered refuge to La Mettrie after L'Homme Machine made him unwelcome elsewhere. La Mettrie spent his final years at Frederick's court.
Frederick brought Euler to the Berlin Academy, where he worked for 25 years. Their relationship deteriorated over Frederick's preference for French culture.
Herder and Goethe met in Strasbourg (1770) and later both lived in Weimar. Herder influenced the young Goethe's literary development.
Berkeley's Principles of Human Knowledge engages directly with Locke's Essay, accepting empiricism but rejecting Locke's distinction between primary and secondary qualities.
Hume's skepticism about the external world developed Berkeley's critique of Locke further. Hume's Treatise engages with Berkeley's arguments.
Hutcheson's moral sense theory directly developed Shaftesbury's Characteristics. Hutcheson acknowledged this debt explicitly.
Locke supervised the education of the 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury (grandson of Locke's patron). Shaftesbury later critiqued Locke's rejection of innate ideas.
Hutcheson's moral philosophy was partly developed in opposition to Mandeville's cynical Fable of the Bees. Hutcheson insisted on genuine benevolence.
Smith engaged critically with Mandeville's economic ideas, particularly unintended consequences. The 'invisible hand' shows Mandeville's influence, though Smith rejected his moral cynicism.
Burke's political philosophy drew on Montesquieu's historical approach to institutions. Both emphasized tradition and gradual reform over abstract rationalism.
Paine's Rights of Man was written as a direct response to Burke's Reflections on the Revolution in France. This was the defining debate on the French Revolution.
Voltaire wrote a commentary on Beccaria's On Crimes and Punishments, praising and popularizing its arguments for criminal justice reform.
Bentham's utilitarian approach to criminal law reform was directly influenced by Beccaria's On Crimes and Punishments. Bentham acknowledged this influence.
Bentham credited Helvétius's De l'esprit with inspiring his utilitarian philosophy. The principle of utility derived from Helvétius.
Extensive scientific correspondence on electricity and other subjects. Franklin encouraged Priestley's electrical research and helped arrange publication of his History of Electricity.
Priestley was among the first to formulate 'the greatest happiness of the greatest number' principle that Bentham developed into systematic utilitarianism.
Franklin was Paine's patron and mentor. He encouraged Paine's emigration to America (1774), provided letters of introduction, and supported his revolutionary writing.
Collaborated on drafting the Declaration of Independence (1776). Franklin introduced Jefferson to Parisian salons when Jefferson arrived as minister to France (1784).
Jefferson met Condorcet in Parisian salons during his ministry to France. They corresponded on political theory.
Lifelong friendship and political collaboration. Their correspondence is one of the most important in American political thought.
Madison's Federalist No. 10 argument about faction and extended republics drew on Hume's essay 'Idea of a Perfect Commonwealth.'
Served together in Continental Congress and on diplomatic missions. Collaborated on Treaty of Paris negotiations (1782-1783).
Collaborators in Revolution, political rivals (1790s), reconciled correspondents (1812-1826). Both died on July 4, 1826.
Close friendship during Franklin's Paris years. Franklin famously proposed marriage to her. Her salon at Auteuil was his frequent resort.
Extensive mathematical correspondence but also rivalry. They debated priority on various mathematical topics and disagreed on the vibrating string problem.
D'Alembert was Laplace's patron and mentor at the Académie des Sciences. He recognized Laplace's mathematical genius and supported his career.
Important mathematical correspondence. D'Alembert recognized Lagrange's ability and helped him succeed Euler at the Berlin Academy.
Both independently discovered oxygen's role in combustion (1774-1777). They met in Paris and exchanged scientific ideas, though they developed competing interpretations.
Both were members of the Académie des Sciences. Condorcet, as Permanent Secretary, worked closely with Lavoisier on Academy business.
Collaborated on heat experiments in the 1780s using their jointly invented ice calorimeter. Their work on heat capacity was foundational.
Both were prominent figures in Parisian intellectual life. Diderot praised Buffon's Histoire naturelle and shared interests in natural history's philosophical implications.
Geoffrin financially supported the Encyclopédie project. Diderot attended her Wednesday salon for philosophes.
D'Alembert was a regular at Geoffrin's salon. She supported philosophes generally and connected them with influential aristocrats.
Montesquieu attended Geoffrin's salon before his death in 1755. The salon was a meeting place for philosophes across generations.
Very close relationship. D'Alembert lived in her house for years. Her salon became a key meeting place for philosophes.
Condorcet was a regular at her salon. She introduced him to influential figures and provided a venue for philosophical discussion.
Turgot attended her salon and met other philosophes there, including Condorcet.
Regular correspondence spanning decades. Voltaire valued her literary judgment and wit.
Montesquieu frequented her salon in the 1720s-1750s. She was an early and fashionable hostess.
Catherine purchased Diderot's library in 1765, allowing him to keep it during his lifetime. Diderot visited her court in 1773-1774 for extensive conversations.
Catherine invited d'Alembert to Russia (he declined). They corresponded on Enlightenment themes; she sought to cultivate her image as an enlightened ruler.
Newton's Principia Mathematica (1687) established mathematical physics and the mechanistic worldview
Newton published Opticks in 1704, establishing the corpuscular theory of light
Locke's Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1689) is the foundational text of empiricism
Locke's Two Treatises of Government (1689) established liberal political philosophy
Locke's Letter Concerning Toleration (1689) argued for religious freedom
Leibniz's Theodicy (1710) argued this is the best of all possible worlds
Leibniz wrote the Monadology in 1714, outlining his metaphysical system
Shaftesbury's Characteristics (1711) developed moral sense theory
Mandeville's Fable of the Bees (1714) argued private vices produce public benefits
Montesquieu published Persian Letters anonymously in 1721
Montesquieu's Spirit of the Laws (1748) articulated separation of powers
Voltaire's Letters on the English (1733) introduced English philosophy to France
Voltaire co-authored Elements of the Philosophy of Newton with du Châtelet
Du Châtelet collaborated with Voltaire on Elements of the Philosophy of Newton
Du Châtelet wrote Institutions de physique (1740) synthesizing Newtonian and Leibnizian physics
Du Châtelet's French translation of Newton's Principia remains the standard today
Voltaire wrote Candide (1759) satirizing Leibnizian optimism
Voltaire's Philosophical Dictionary (1764) collected his philosophical provocations
D'Alembert's Traité de dynamique (1743) made major contributions to mechanics
D'Alembert wrote the famous Preliminary Discourse to the Encyclopédie (1751)
Diderot was chief editor of the Encyclopédie (1751-1772)
D'Alembert was co-editor of the Encyclopédie until 1758
Condillac's Essay on the Origin of Human Knowledge (1746) extended Locke's empiricism
Condillac's Treatise on Sensations (1754) systematically developed sensationalism
La Mettrie's Natural History of the Soul (1745) was an early statement of his materialism
La Mettrie's Man a Machine (1747) argued humans are purely material machines
Rousseau's Discourse on Inequality (1755) argued civilization corrupted natural goodness
Rousseau's Social Contract (1762) theorized legitimate political authority
Rousseau's Emile (1762) revolutionized educational philosophy
Helvétius's De l'esprit (1758) caused scandal with its utilitarian ethics
Quesnay's Tableau économique (1758) was the first attempt to model economic flows
D'Holbach published Christianity Unveiled (1761) anonymously
D'Holbach's System of Nature (1770) was comprehensive atheist philosophy
Turgot's Reflections on Wealth (1766) was a major economic treatise
Condorcet's Sketch for Progress (1795) was a classic statement of Enlightenment optimism
Condorcet applied probability to voting theory in his 1785 essay
Berkeley's Principles of Human Knowledge (1710) developed idealist empiricism
Berkeley's Three Dialogues (1713) defended his immaterialism accessibly
Hutcheson's Inquiry (1725) systematically developed moral sense theory
Hume's Treatise of Human Nature (1739) was his masterpiece of radical empiricism
Hume's Enquiry (1748) analyzed causation and miracles
Hume's History of England (1754-1761) was the most widely read history of the century
Hume's Dialogues (1779) devastatingly critiqued arguments for God's existence
Kames's Essays (1751) explored moral sense and natural religion
Kames's Elements of Criticism (1762) developed a systematic theory of aesthetic taste
Reid's Inquiry (1764) founded Common Sense philosophy against Hume's skepticism
Ferguson's Essay on Civil Society (1767) was a pioneer work of sociology
Robertson's History of Scotland (1759) established him as a major historian
Smith's Theory of Moral Sentiments (1759) based ethics on sympathy
Smith's Wealth of Nations (1776) founded classical economics
Burke's Sublime and Beautiful (1757) influenced aesthetic theory including Kant's
Burke's Reflections (1790) was the founding text of conservatism
Bentham's Principles (1789) systematically stated utilitarianism
Wolff's German Logic (1713) was the first major philosophical work in German
Baumgarten's Aesthetica (1750) coined the term and founded aesthetics as discipline
Baumgarten's Metaphysica (1739) became Kant's standard teaching text
Lessing's Laocoon (1766) distinguished temporal from spatial arts
Lessing's Nathan the Wise (1779) promoted religious tolerance
Mendelssohn's Phädon (1767) was a modern version of Plato's dialogue on immortality
Mendelssohn's Jerusalem (1783) defended Jewish practice and church-state separation
Herder's Treatise on Language (1772) argued language emerged naturally
Herder's Ideas (1784-1791) emphasized cultural diversity in history
Kant's Critique of Pure Reason (1781) transformed philosophy
Kant's essay (1784) defined the Enlightenment: Sapere aude
Kant's Critique of Practical Reason (1788) established his systematic ethics
Kant's Critique of Judgment (1790) analyzed aesthetic and teleological judgment
Beccaria's On Crimes and Punishments (1764) revolutionized criminal justice
Franklin's Experiments on Electricity (1751) established his scientific reputation
Paine's Common Sense (1776) was the most widely read pamphlet of the American Revolution
Paine's Rights of Man (1791) defended the French Revolution against Burke
Paine's Age of Reason (1794) promoted deism and critiqued organized religion
Jefferson was the principal author of the Declaration of Independence (1776)
Jefferson authored the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom (1786)
Jefferson's Notes on Virginia (1785) was his only full-length book
Madison was a principal author of the Federalist Papers (1787-1788)
Lavoisier's Elements of Chemistry (1789) founded modern chemistry
Buffon's Histoire naturelle (1749-1804) was the most widely read scientific work
Newton was Lucasian Professor at Cambridge from 1669 to 1702
Newton moved to London in 1696 as Warden of the Royal Mint
Newton was President of the Royal Society from 1703 until his death
Locke spent significant time in London in political and intellectual circles
Hume was born in Edinburgh and spent most of his life there
Hume served as secretary to the British embassy in Paris 1763-1766
Smith lived in Glasgow during his professorship 1751-1764
Smith was Professor of Moral Philosophy at Glasgow 1752-1764
Smith spent his final years in Edinburgh 1778-1790
Smith visited Paris in 1765-1766 and met the Physiocrats
Hutcheson was Professor of Moral Philosophy at Glasgow 1729-1746
Reid succeeded Adam Smith as Professor at Glasgow in 1764
Robertson was Principal of University of Edinburgh 1762-1793
Ferguson was Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh
Kames was a prominent figure in Edinburgh intellectual life
Stewart was Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh
Berkeley spent significant time in London before becoming Bishop
Shaftesbury was active in London political and intellectual circles
Mandeville settled in London and practiced medicine there
Burke was active in London as a statesman and writer
Priestley lived in London before fleeing to America in 1794
Bentham spent most of his life in London
Hume was a founding member of the Select Society (1754)
Smith was a member of the Select Society
Ferguson was a member of the Select Society

Voltaire lived at his estate at Ferney from 1758 until his death
Voltaire lived at Cirey with Émilie du Châtelet 1734-1749
Du Châtelet and Voltaire collaborated at Cirey château
Diderot spent his career in Paris editing the Encyclopédie
D'Alembert was born and lived his entire life in Paris
Rousseau lived in Paris during his involvement with the philosophes

Montesquieu spent significant time in Paris salons
D'Holbach lived in Paris and hosted his famous salon there
Helvétius lived in Paris and hosted a salon
Condillac was active in Parisian intellectual circles
Condorcet spent his career in Paris

Jaucourt worked on the Encyclopédie in Paris

Buffon directed the Jardin du Roi in Paris
Lavoisier worked in Paris at the Académie des Sciences
Laplace spent his career in Paris
Lagrange moved to Paris in 1787 after leaving Berlin

Lespinasse hosted her salon in Paris
Du Deffand hosted her literary salon in Paris
